forumNotes.author: mr_
forumNotes.content:
What I want to reach:  
having a drive with Volume Boot Record only booting method, without MBR.  

What I've tested already:  
Method a)  
1) wiped first sector with HxD Hex Editor  
2) save removed pendrive and pluged it into a machine without filter driver  
3) fast formatted the drive with FAT (windows recognized the full 1 GB size of the pendrive)  
4) did copy NTLDR, NTDETECT.COM and BOOT.INI to it  
5) booted it with PLoP  

Method b)  
1) wiped first sector with HxD Hex Editor  
2) created a floppy disk with XP create MS-DOS startup disk  
3) extracted first logical sector on A:\\ with hd hacker  
4) did load the file into hd hacker and wrote it into the physical pendrive number  
5) save removed the pendrive and plug it in again (windows reconized 1.44 MB)  
5) booted it with PLoP  

Method c)  
Used MKBT but I think it does basically the same as method b).  

Question:  
In any case the stick boots, this is the good news that inital booting is working. But I get "Invalid system disk, Replace the disk, and then press any key" which is a message from the bootcode. How can I manage it to turn this error message into a bootable DOS or grub4dos?

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
> What I want to reach:  
> having a drive with Volume Boot Record only booting method, without MBR.
A hint:  

[http://www.memtest86.com/download.html](http://www.memtest86.com/download.html "External link")  
USB key image contains a hard disk like image.  

Extract partition and write to physical drive.  
A mkdosfs/syslinux boot record is used.  
Qemu does boot PhysicalDrive.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
**mr_** if it's a USB stick, most probably you could make one the easy way by using makebootfat. (having also the advantage of the double use MBR bootsesctor) Some details are here: [http://www.911cd.net...o...13784\&st=44](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=13784&st=44 "External link") In any case test the result with "normal" booting of the image in Qemu, and once succeede, introduce PLoP "variation". Other method is using filedisk or VDK/fsz, details are in this thread: [http://www.911cd.net...o...c=19333\&hl=](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=19333&hl= "External link") The error you are getting now seems like a problem in the bootsector data, typically need a check: * media descriptor * hidden sectors * physical drive number
See these: [http://www.scribd.co...t-Sector-Format](http://www.scribd.com/doc/40600/MSDOS-Boot-Sector-Format "External link") [http://home.att.net/...ot/w95bboot.htm](http://home.att.net/~rayknights/pc_boot/w95bboot.htm "External link") jaclaz

forumNotes.content:

Sounds reasonable.

I do not see the relation to VBR only booting, in the end he says  
> Format your USB (flash) drive with a utility (e.g. with standard XP format, HP utility, pe2usb, ...)  
> (we need a drive with standard MBR calling NTLDR)
which is again about normal MBR booting.  

Also for what I should need filedisk when I want to make a physical drive bootable? His format command is also not special format R: /FS:NTFS /C /V:RAMPE
/C is for compression what I do not need and /V for description, FS:NTFS is set automatically when formatting with default gui.  

The thread is basically about creating a bootable CD containing an pe image (VBR only) with ram booting starting from USB. Not really what I am looking for.  

> The error you are getting now seems like a problem in the bootsector data, typically need a check:
Probable. I do not think I can invert how to fix it with a hex editor.  

> **mr_**   
> if it's a USB stick, most probably you could make one the easy way by using makebootfat. (having also the advantage of the double use MBR bootsesctor)
That's an other interesting field for research but I am not sure whenever it solves more problems then it creates as there are not enough reports. In past I hadn't much luck with triple MBR booting.  

For this reason I would be glad in a "more native" VBR only booting creation method.

forumNotes.author: cdob
forumNotes.content:
Given MS default boot code: There is a disk error, if CHS LBA translation fails. I undertand: FAT12 and FAT16 boot code use CHS only. [http://mirror.href.c...br/WIN98FDB.htm](http://mirror.href.com/thestarman/asm/mbr/WIN98FDB.htm "External link") Using FAT12 and FAT16 floppy image at PhysiclaDrive: The BIOS does most likely map CHS different to boot code: boot code fails with a disk error. Syslinux patch the boot sector to load file ldlinux.sys. There is a absolute pointer. Solution is indepenent from CHS LBA translation.
At FAT32 and NTFS boot code this can be overcome using LBA only. [http://blog.clemens....ndows_3170.html](http://blog.clemens.endorphin.org/2007/12/removing-chs-based-access-from-windows_3170.html "External link") Try a FAT32 or NTFS floppy image and remove CHS from boot code. Overall a MS default boot code dosn't support different CHS LBA translation.

Are you looking for a bootsector invoking NTLDR or one invoking IO.SYS?  

jaclaz

```
SYSLINUX 3.72 2008-09-25 EBIOS Copyright (C) 1994-2008 H. Peter Anvin
```

and also

```
Should be a disk image
```

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
Well, I never said to use MBRBatch ![:good:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/good.gif): > Basically you need to know the EXACT size of the USB stick, a method (a bit slow though) is to copy the whole stick using dsfo/dsfi. > > If you have just one drive, it will be \\\\.\\PhysicalDrive***0*** and the USB stick will be \\\\.\\PhysicalDrive***1*** (change drive number for your situation) > > Now, open a command prompt in the directory where the batch and tools are and: > > ``` > dsfo \\.\PHYSICALDRIVE1 0 0 NUL > ``` > > this will copy the whole stick to the NUL device (thus occupying NO space on any of your drives), you'll get something like this: > > OK, 128000000 bytes, 6.540s, MD5 = 786a48c5db7548a6bf34cb945b62ae75 > > Jolt down the number of transferred bytes, 128000000 in this example. > >
>
OK, I'l sse what I can do with a 1 Gb***ish*** image....![^_^](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy.png) ![^_^](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy.png) jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
@mr_ I'm a bit stumped. ![^_^](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy.png) I re-tested the makebootfat approach, and it does work, though I seemed to remember that I tested a "direct boot-sector" approach at the time of my first experiments with Qemu, now it doesn't work. Cannot say if it's my memory fading ![:good:](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/good.gif) or if it is some form of "regression" in Qemu latest builds. ![^_^](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy.png) "Simple"/replicable how to: Tools needed: a NTFS volume, say C:\\ mksparse: [http://www.acc.umu.se/\~bosse/](http://www.acc.umu.se/~bosse/ "External link") (the NTFS volume and mksparse are advised as the image will take only a few Kb on disk instead of the whole size) VDK.EXE: [http://chitchat.at.i...vmware/vdk.html](http://chitchat.at.infoseek.co.jp/vmware/vdk.html "External link") optionally with my pseudo-GUI for it: [http://home.graffiti...ts/VDM/vdm.html](http://home.graffiti.net/jaclaz:graffiti.net/Projects/VDM/vdm.html "External link") Windows 9x System files: IO.SYS MSDOS.SYS COMMAND.COM Beeblebrox: [http://students.cs.byu.edu/\~codyb/](http://students.cs.byu.edu/~codyb/ "External link") or similar partition table editor or a hex editor capable of accessing \\\\.\\PHYSICALDRIVEs makebootfat: [http://advancemame.s...akebootfat.html](http://advancemame.sourceforge.net/doc-makebootfat.html "External link") [http://advancemame.s...t-download.html](http://advancemame.sourceforge.net/boot-download.html "External link") Make a directory on your drive, say C:\\myimage and within it a subdir C:\\myimage\\win98boot\\ , copy to C:\\myimage\\win98boot\\ the Win9x system files. Extract from any existing FAT16 volume (with the "right" code, in this case the one invoking IO.SYS) for example using hdhacker or a hex editor or make one with bootpart as detailed here: [http://www.911cd.net...o...13784\&st=44](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=13784&st=44 "External link") and save it, in my case, as C:\\myimage\\Win41.bin Make sure you also extract in C:\\myimage\\mbrfat.bin the mbrfat.bin inside the makebootfat package. Calculate an "even" number for size for the image (advised if it will be used with grub4dos and to assure max compatibility with everything), with the desired geometry, as an example: Geometry ***n*** x64x32: 1,048,576,000/32=32,768,000 32,768,000/64=512,000 512,000/512=1,000 Cylinders "even", OK ![^_^](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy.png) Geometry ***n*** x255x63: 1,048,576,000/63=÷16,644,063.49 16,644,063/255=÷65,270.83 65.270/512=÷127.48 Cylinders "odd", NOT ok ![^_^](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/happy.png) So, let's round it up to 127x255x63=2,040,255 sectorsx512=1,044,610,560 bytes VDK will default to a geometry of ***n*** x64x32, if you use it you won't need to create a .pln file, if you use any other geometry, it will be needed. Create the image: ``` mksparse c:\myimage\1stimage.img 1044610560 ```
Create a plain TEXT file with Notepad or similar app and save it as C:\\myimage\\1stimage.pln, and write in it: > DRIVETYPE ide > CYLINDERS 127 > HEADS 255 > SECTORS 63 > ACCESS "C:\\myimage\\1stimage.img" 0 2040255 Or use the small batch makepln (attached) or here: [http://www.forensicf...m...c\&p=6524785](http://www.forensicfocus.com/index.php?name=Forums&file=viewtopic&p=6524785 "External link") Now, mount the .pln (NOT the .img) with VDK.EXE, and use beeblebrox or the hex editor, or any other program, to determine which \\\\.\\PHYSICALDRIVE***n*** it got. In my case it is \\\\.\\PHYSICALDRIVE**8** , thus: ``` makebootfat -o \\.\PhysicalDrive8 -2 C:\myimage\win41.bin -m C:\myimage\mbrfat.bin -F -v C:\myimage\bootfiles ```
Unmount the image from VDK.EXE. That's all. It boots allright in Qemu (but only when mounted as (hd0)), thus there is no way to know if the "direct bootsector" approach works. Chainloading it through grub4dos works allright, but when the image is mounted as either (fd0) or (fd1) in Qemu, something "goes beserk" and even grub4dos mapping outputs an error. What works is (having the image as a hd in Qemu) and with a grub4dos floppy as boot device: ``` map (hd0) (fd1) map --hook rootnoverify (fd1) chainloader +1 ```
and ``` map (hd0) (fd1) map --hook rootnoverify (fd1) chainloader +64 ```
Do you have any "real" hardware that allows ONLY booting from USB "superfloppy" to test? jaclaz #### Attached Files {#attach_wrap} * [![Attached File](http://reboot.pro/public/style_extra/mime_types/zip.gif)](http://reboot.pro/index.php?s=3c197f289d1c3aea0620c0edd45f613b&app=core&module=attach§ion=attach&attach_id=8031 "Download attachment") [**makepln.7z**](http://reboot.pro/index.php?s=3c197f289d1c3aea0620c0edd45f613b&app=core&module=attach§ion=attach&attach_id=8031 "Download attachment") **1.13KB** 344 downloads

I need to know if it makes a difference with FAT16 or FAT32. I need: * the copy of the first sector of your USB stick, ANYONE that **works** for you (no matter if partitioned or not) use HDhacker to get first sector of the PHYSICALDRIVE) * the copy of first sector of the partition (if partitioned) i.e. first sector of LOGICALDRIVE. * the exact, in bytes, size of the stick, use this method: [http://www.boot-land...?...c=5000\&st=1](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=5000&st=1 "External link")
